results.creator_credit: Annenberg, CPB Project, PBI Productions and Westview Press

Episode of Series “The Pacific century”.

results.title: Marlon Brando
results.creator_credit: Claudio Masenza, Donatella Baglivo and Ciak Studio
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hollywood’s rebels”.
This documentary highlights the experiences of those that worked with Marlon Brando, whether cast or crew, throughout his career, and provides a unique insight into the man himself. Director Claudio Masenza has collated a myriad of interviews from colleagues, friends and family, as well as stills and film clips to give a thorough overview of Brando’s acting career, and although much praise is bestowed on the star the rebellious presence of Brando on the Hollywood stage is also discussed. Candid accounts and anecdotes make up this portrayal of Brando’s darker side in tandem with a sensitive discussion of the talent that made Brando one of the most sought after actors in Hollywood following his debut in the 1950s.

results.title: James Dean
results.creator_credit: Claudio Masenza, Donatella Baglivo and Ciak Studio
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hollywood’s rebels”.
James Dean was a 1950s icon whose image fought against all that was wrong with the adult world: displacement of the young, repression, and general uncoolness. This documentary however focuses on James Dean the man, rather than his image. It is an illuminating look at the actor’s life seen through the eyes of friends, family and work colleagues. The testimonials are frank and thought provoking, and there is rare footage of TV commercials and telemovies that Dean had featured in. It shows an extremely talented and ambitious actor who often seemed more comfortable on stage or in front of a camera than he did being himself. Refreshingly it also highlights other sides to Dean such as his wicked sense of humour. The interviewees speak candidly and articulately of stories that are not a staple of the James Dean myth, leaving one with a real sense of whom this young man was as an actor.

results.title: Montgomery Clift: the prince
results.creator_credit: Claudio Masenza, Donatella Baglivo and Ciak Studio
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hollywood’s rebels”.
A documentary incorporating footage of Montgomery Clift’s most memorable films; interviews with family and with friends of Clift (including Jane Fonda); and rare archival material stretching back to his childhood. What develops is the story of an intense young boy who yearned for stardom, achieved notable success in such classic films as “From Here to Eternity” and “I Confess”, only to be ruined by alcohol addiction and his inability to face his own fears and homosexual desires. Montgomery Clift, as this video portrays him, may have not been a happy man but he never compromised his acting talents for Hollywood.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Claudio Masenza, Donatella Baglivo and Ciak Studio

results.title: The Painter's world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present
results.brief_description: A six-part series which explores how and why paintings are made. Each program traces the development of a given subject from the Renaisance to the present, showing how artists can act both conventionally within or radically against constants, always responding to existing works and conditions.

results.title: Painting and the public: patronage, museums and the art market
results.creator_credit: Judith Wechsler, Linda Zuck, Channel 4, Illuminations Films and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
The way we see works of art, and therefore value them is one of the key changing constants of art. This program looks at the history of the economics and the exhibition of art from the Renaissance to the present, beginning with the great Renaissance patrons, including the Medicis and the Popes, through the royal collections of France, the development of art museums and the current chaos of the art market.

results.title: The Artist and the nude
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
The human body has been the most persistent theme in art. Sinners and saints, children and old men and, of course, women, have all appeared nude in art over the centuries. The nude has been used both as a vehicle for competing ideals of beauty and to portray independent visions of reality. This program details the nude’s changing roles in art and examines why this popular form, though closest to home is hardest to master.

results.title: The Arrested moment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
This program explores how painters have achieved movement in a still image and have told stories in a single frame. Before photography, it did not occur to artists to isolate single moments. Medieval art saw the eternal moment, but with Renaissance art action became central. The program looks at how Michelangelo, Raphael, Titian, Leonardo and Caravaggio treated movement and then moves to the post-photography era and the works of Muybridge, Hockney, Duchamp and Pollock.

results.title: Abstraction
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
20th century art has been dominated by Abstraction which could be said to be its legacy to art. This program traces the antecedents of Abstraction in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, and then goes on to explore the work of notable Abstractionists, such as Miro, Kandinsky, Mondrian, Barnett Newman, Pollock, Rothko, and Frank Stella, stressing the risk taking aspects of this form of art, and dividing it into two main strands - the geometric and analytic, and that inspired by organic life.
